awd_titl_txt: Experimental calibration of stable isotope and REE partitioning in bioapatite
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical description:
The geochemistry of biogenic calcium phosphate (bioapatite) is widely used in studies of paleoclimatology, paleoecology, paleoceanography, anthropology/archeology, fossil forensics, geochronology, and tooth caries. Many such endeavors are compromised by poor understanding of the fractionation of stable isotopes of oxygen and carbon in structural carbonate (CO3), and partitioning of rare-earth elements (REE) between bioapatite and aqueous solutions. Stable isotope fractionations and REE partition coefficients will be measured by synthesizing bioapatite in isotopically- and chemically- characterized solutions at temperatures ranging from 10 to 60 °C. Particular emphasis will be placed on identifying the crystallographic site of CO3 substitution as a control on isotope fractionations, calibrating spectroscopic measurements of tooth chemistry, and characterizing particle sizes and surface areas to distinguish intracrystalline vs. adsorption partition coefficients for REE. Time-series experiments will be conducted to ensure close approach to equilibrium, and past experimental methods will be reproduced for improved particle size characterization and comparison to new chemical and isotopic data.
 
Non-technical/Broader impacts:
This grant funds a comprehensive calibration of the geochemical behavior of bioapatite - the mineral that constitutes bones and teeth. This work is important for validating past research and improving quantitative interpretations in numerous fields ranging from paleoclimate and paleoceanography to anthropology, forensic discrimination of fossils, geochronology and possibly dental stability. Specifically, we will calibrate methods to determine the carbonate (CO3) content of bioapatite, which strongly controls tooth enamel solubility, and synthesize bioapatites with different CO3 contents. The tendency for bioapatite to accumulate lanthanide-group elements and the heavy isotopes of oxygen and carbon will be calibrated and compared with sparse previous measurements. These data will inform past interpretations of modern tooth and fossil geochemistry and improve targeting of future studies involving modern and fossil teeth. Educational outreach includes research training for a graduate student, and development of undergraduate research for underrepresented groups. Additional training includes development of mentorship skills for a young female research scientist. Boise State serves a large proportion of returning and part-time students with an average undergraduate age of 27. Thus, research and education activities impact a different demographic than at most other universities.

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in numerous outcomes of diverse impact across the Earth Sciences and related fields:

1) We have refined methods for synthesizing bioapatite that minimizes nitrogen contamination. Such results have value for basic Earth Sciences research, and may have benefit to industrial or medical applications.

2) We have calibrated infrared spectra quantitatively for carbonate substitution amounts in bioapatites. These data help us discriminate alteration of fossils and better interpret ancient paleoecological and paleoclimatic conditions.

3) We have begun calibrating rare-earth element partitioning between bioapatite and aqueous solutions. This work has major implications for interpreting trace element patterns in fossils and for designing and applying toxicological research on trace element uptake in humans.

4) We have discovered that isotopic systematics in tooth enamel are simpler than assumed and facilitate both interpretations of isotope variations and sampling methods.

5) Metadata analysis of carbon isotopes in terrestrial plants shows independence from atmospheric CO2 levels. This result simplifies interpretation of past climates and ecosystems, as well as models of carbon cycling in modern Earth.

6) Interlaboratory comparison of sample preparation and analytical methods demonstrates that the main cause of discrepancies among laboratories is analytical standardization method. This results vastly simplifies intercomparison among laboratories and reconciliation of past data.

7) A new method for investigating the ecology and physiology of birds and dinosaurs was developed.

8) The impact of abrupt climate change on temperature gradients and precipitation patterns in central North America was quantified for the Eocene-Oligocene transition.

9) Global warming affects the southwestern deserts of the US by reducing summer precipitation. Continued global warming may compromise the sustainability of desert wetlands and the ecosystems that depend on these water sources.

10) Our activities have helped train PhD students Robin Trayler and Amanda Drewicz in methods of bioapatite synthesis, trace element and isotopic analysis, data compilation, and data interpretation, particularly in the context of global climate and ecological change. Undergraduate Jessica Bohn also received training in bioapatite synthesis, trace element analysis, and electron beam imaging of experimental run products.

11) A public lecture was presented regarding the evidence for and expected future changes associated with global warming. An inaugural article on bioapatite mineral geochemistry was prepared for the Mineralogical Society of America, targeted towards a high-school audience, illustrating the value of minerals to geosciences research and society.
